Office#Solar System Exploration|Solar System Exploration program]]''' | previous_mission = [[Double Asteroid Redirection Test|DART]] | next_mission = }} '''Europa Clipper''' (previously known as '''Europa Multiple Flyby Mission''') is a [[space probe]] in development by [[NASA]]. Planned for launch in October 2024, the spacecraft is being developed to study the [[Galilean moons|Galilean moon]] [[Europa (moon)|Europa]] through a series of [[Flyby (spaceflight)|flybys]] while in orbit around [[Jupiter]].{{cite news |last=Clark |first=Stuart |title='It's like finding needles in a haystack': the mission to discover if Jupiter's moons support life |url=https://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/mar/05/could-jupiters-icy-moons-support-life |date=5 March 2023 |work=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=7 March 2023 }}{{Cite web |last=King |first=Lucinda |last2=Conversation |first2=The |title=If life exists on Jupiter's moon Europa, scientists might soon be able to detect it |url=https://phys.org/news/2024-04-life-jupiter-moon-europa-scientists.html |access-date=2024-04-08 |website=phys.org |language=en}} It is the largest spacecraft NASA has ever developed for a planetary mission.{{Cite web |date=2024-04-19 |title=How our vision of Europa’s habitability is changing |url=https://www.sciencenews.org/article/vision-europa-habitability-jupiter-moon |access-date=2024-04-24 |language=en-US}} This mission is a scheduled flight of the Planetary Science Division, designated a [[Large strategic science missions|Large Strategic Science Mission]], and funded under the [[Planetary Missions Program Office]]'s [[Planetary Missions Program Office|Solar System Exploration program]] as its second flight.{{Cite web |last1=Wolfe |first1=Alexis |last2=McDonald |first2=Lisa |date=July 21, 2017 |title=Balance of NASA Planetary Science Missions Explored at Hearing |url=https://www.aip.org/fyi/2017/balance-nasa-planetary-science-missions-explored-hearing |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200731023935/https://www.aip.org/fyi/2017/balance-nasa-planetary-science-missions-explored-hearing |archive-date=July 31, 2020 |access-date=May 29, 2019 |publisher=American Institute of Physics}}{{Cite web |title=Solar System Exploration Missions List |url=https://planetarymissions.nasa.gov/missions/solar%20system%20exploration |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://archive.today/20180327141053/https://planetarymissions.nasa.gov/missions/solar%20system%20exploration |archive-date=March 27, 2018 |access-date=March 27, 2018 |website=Planetary Missions Program Office (PMPO) |publisher=NASA}} {{PD-notice}} It is also supported by the new [[Ocean Worlds Exploration Program]]. ''Europa Clipper'' will perform follow-up studies to those made by the ''[[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]]'' spacecraft during its eight years (1995 – 2003) in Jupiter orbit, which indicated the existence of a subsurface ocean underneath Europa's ice [[Crust (geology)|crust]]. Plans to send a spacecraft to Europa were initially conceived with projects such as ''[[Europa Orbiter]]'' and ''[[Jupiter Icy Moons Orbiter]]'', in which a spacecraft would be injected into orbit around Europa. However, due to the adverse effects of [[radiation]] from [[Magnetosphere of Jupiter|Jupiter's magnetosphere]] in Europa orbit, it was decided that it would be safer to inject a spacecraft into an [[Elliptic orbit|elliptical orbit]] around Jupiter and make 44 close flybys of the moon instead. The mission began as a joint investigation between the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] (JPL) and the [[Applied Physics Laboratory]] (APL), and will be built with a scientific payload of nine instruments contributed by [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory|JPL]], [[Applied Physics Laboratory|APL]], [[Southwest Research Institute]], [[University of Texas at Austin]], [[Arizona State University]] and [[University of Colorado Boulder]]. The upcoming mission complements [[ESA]]'s [[Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer]] launch in 2023, which will fly-by Europa twice and [[Callisto (moon)|Callisto]] multiple times before moving into orbit around [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]]. The mission is scheduled to launch in October 2024 aboard a [[Falcon Heavy]], during a 21-day launch window. The spacecraft will use [[gravity assist]]s from Mars in February 2025 and Earth in December 2026, before arriving at Europa in April 2030. == History == [[File:Repeated Flybys Yield a Pole-to-Pole View of Europa.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|The flybys of Europa by a previous mission collected the data for this mosaic.]] In 1997, a ''[[Europa Orbiter]]'' mission was proposed by a team for NASA's [[Discovery Program|Discovery program]]{{Cite conference |last1=Edwards |first1=Bradley C. |last2=Chyba |first2=Christopher F. |last3=Abshire |first3=James B. |last4=Burns |first4=Joseph A. |last5=Geissler |first5=Paul |last6=Konopliv |first6=Alex S. |last7=Malin |first7=Michael C. |last8=Ostro |first8=Steven J. |last9=Rhodes |first9=Charley |date=July 11, 1997 |title=The Europa Ocean Discovery mission |conference=Proc. SPIE 3111, Instruments, Methods, and Missions for the Investigation of Extraterrestrial Microorganisms |doi=10.1117/12.278778 |first10=Chuck |last10=Rudiger |first11=Xuan-Min |last11=Shao |first12=David E. |last12=Smith |first13=Steven W. |last13=Squyres |first14=Peter C. |last14=Thomas |first15=Chauncey W. |last15=Uphoff |first16=Gerald D. |last16=Walberg |first17=Charles L. |last17=Werner |first18=Charles F. |last18=Yoder |first19=Maria T. |last19=Zuber}} but was not selected. NASA's JPL announced one month after the selection of Discovery proposals that a NASA Europa orbiter mission would be conducted. JPL then invited the Discovery proposal team to be the Mission Review Committee (MRC).{{citation needed|date=September 2020}} At the same time as the proposal of the Discovery-class ''Europa Orbiter'', the robotic ''[[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo]]'' spacecraft was already orbiting Jupiter. From December 8, 1995, to December 7, 1997 ''Galileo'' conducted the primary mission after entering the orbit of Jupiter. On that final date, the Galileo orbiter commenced an extended mission known as the ''Galileo'' Europa Mission (GEM), which ran until December 31, 1999. This was a low-cost mission extension, with a budget of only US$30 million. The smaller team of about 40–50 people (one-fifth the size of the primary mission's 200-person team from 1995–1997) did not have the resources to deal with problems, but when they arose it was able to temporarily recall former team members (called "tiger teams") for intensive efforts to solve them. The spacecraft made several flybys of [[Europa (moon)|Europa]] (8), [[Callisto (moon)|Callisto]] (4) and [[Io (moon)|Io]] (2). On each flyby of the three moons it encountered, the spacecraft collected only two days' worth of data instead of the seven it had collected during the primary mission. This ''Galileo'' Europa Mission was similar to a small-scale version of what the ''Europa Clipper'' is planning to accomplish. GEM included eight flybys of Europa, ranging from {{cvt|196|to|3582|km}}, in two years.{{Cite book |last=Meltzer |first=Michael |url=https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4231/sp4231.pdf |title=Mission to Jupiter: A History of the ''Galileo'' Project |publisher=NASA |year=2007 |series=The NASA History Series |oclc=124150579 |id=SP-4231 |access-date=December 4, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201128052208/https://history.nasa.gov/SP-4231/sp4231.pdf |archive-date=November 28, 2020 |url-status=live}} {{PD-notice}} Europa has been identified as one (spacecraft)|''Galileo'']] spacecraft's discoveries and the independent Discovery program proposal for a Europa orbiter, JPL conducted preliminary mission studies that envisioned a capable spacecraft such as the [[Jupiter Icy Moons Orbiter]] (a US$16 billion mission concept),{{Cite web |date=2005 |title=Project Prometheus final report – page 178 |url=http://trs-new.jpl.nasa.gov/dspace/bitstream/2014/38185/1/05-3441.pdf |url-status=dead the [[Jupiter Europa Orbiter]] (a US$4.3 billion concept), another orbiter (US$2 billion concept), and a multi-flyby spacecraft: ''Europa Clipper''. A mission to Europa was recommended by the [[National Research Council (United States)|National Research Council]] in 2013. The approximate cost estimate rose from US$2 billion in 2013 to US$4.25 billion in 2020.{{cite news|url=https://spacenews.com/europa-clipper-passes-key-review/|title=Europa Clipper passes key review|author=Jeff Foust|date=August 22, 2019|publisher=[[Space News]]|access-date=July 4, 2023}}[https://www.space.com/nasa-europa-mission-alien-life.html NASA Europa Mission Could Potentially Spot Signs of Alien Life] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210126130808/https://www.space.com/nasa-europa-mission-alien-life.html |date=January 26, 2021 }}, Mike Wall, ''Space.com'', October 26, 2019 The mission is a joint project between the [[Johns Hopkins University]]'s [[Applied Physics Laboratory]] (APL), and the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] (JPL).{{Cite conference |last1=Pappalardo |first1=Robert |last2=Cooke |first2=Brian |last3=Goldstein |first3=Barry |last4=Prockter |first4=Louise |last5=Senske |first5=Dave |last6=Magner |first6=Tom |date=July 2013 |title=OPAG Update |publisher=Lunar and Planetary Institute |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210125054349/https://www.lpi.usra.edu/opag/jul2013/presentations/Clipper_Summary.pdf |archive-date=January 25, 2021 |access-date=December 13, 2013 |contribution=The Europa Clipper |contribution-url=http://www.lpi.usra.edu/opag/jul2013/presentations/Clipper_Summary.pdf |url-status=live}} The mission's name is a reference to the lightweight [[clipper|clipper ships]] of the 19th century that routinely plied trade routes around the world.{{Cite web |last=Dyches |first=Preston |date=March 9, 2017 |title=NASA Mission Named 'Europa Clipper' |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=6772 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202164049/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=6772 |archive-date=December 2, 2020 |access-date=October 28, 2017 |publisher=JPL (NASA)}} {{PD-notice}} The moniker was chosen because the spacecraft will "sail" past Europa, as frequently as every two weeks. ===End of mission planning=== In June 2022, project scientist Robert Pappalardo revealed that mission planners for ''Europa Clipper'' were considering disposing of the probe by crashing it into the surface of [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]] for [[planetary protection|Europan protection]] purposes, in case an extended mission was not approved early. He noted that an impact would help the [[European Space Agency|ESA]]'s [[Jupiter Icy Moons Explorer|JUICE]] mission collect more information about Ganymede's surface chemistry.{{cite web | title=14 OPAG June 2022 Day 2 Bob Pappalardo Jordan Evans (unlisted) | website=YouTube | date=July 19, 2022 | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eKD6fuWUIlw&t=624 | access-date=April 15, 2024}}{{cite web | last=Waldek | first=Stefanie | title=NASA's Europa Clipper may crash into Ganymede, the largest moon in the solar system, at mission's end | website=Space.com | date=June 29, 2022 | url=https://www.space.com/europa-clipper-might-crash-into-ganymede | access-date=April 15, 2024}} == Objectives == [[File:Photo composite of suspected water plumes on Europa.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|The photo composite of suspected water plumes on Europa]] [[File:EuropaClipper.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|The concept to achieve global-regional coverage of Europa during successive flybys]] The goals of ''Europa Clipper'' are to explore Europa, investigate its [[Habitability of natural satellites|habitability]] and aid in the selection of a landing site for the future [[Europa Lander (NASA)|Europa Lander]].{{Cite journal |last1=Pappalardo |first1=Robert T. |last2=Vance |first2=S. |last3=Bagenal |first3=F. |last4=Bills |first4=B.G. |last5=Blaney |first5=D.L.|author5-link=Diana Blaney |last6=Blankenship |first6=D.D. |last7=Brinckerhoff |first7=W.B. |last8=Connerney |first8=J.E.P. |last9=Hand |first9=K.P. |last10=Hoehler |first10=T.M. |last11=Leisner |first11=J.S. |last12=Kurth |first12=W.S. |last13=McGrath |first13=M.A. |last14=Mellon |first14=M.T. |last15=Moore |first15=J.M. |year=2013 |title=Science Potential from a Europa Lander |url=https://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/1721.1/81431/2/Pappalardo_Science-potential.pdf |url-status=live |journal=Astrobiology |volume=13 |issue=8 |pages=740–73 |bibcode=2013AsBio..13..740P |doi=10.1089/ast.2013.1003 |pmid=23924246 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134353/https://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/81431/Pappalardo_Science-potential.pdf;jsessionid=FC7BE20FBB7C0C9AA9F45BDF32F8E03D?sequence=2 |archive-date=October 10, 2022 |access-date=October 1, 2019 |hdl-access=free |last16=Patterson |first16=G.W. |last17=Prockter |first17=L.M. |last18=Senske |first18=D.A. |last19=Schmidt |first19=B.E. |last20=Shock |first20=E.L. |last21=Smith |first21=D.E. |last22=Soderlund |first22=K.M. |hdl=1721.1/81431 |s2cid=10522270}} This exploration is focused on understanding the three main requirements for life: [[Water|liquid water]], [[chemistry]], and [[energy]].{{Cite conference |last1=Bayer |first1=Todd |last2=Buffington |first2=Brent |last3=Castet |first3=Jean-Francois |last4=Jackson |first4=Maddalena |last5=Lee |first5=Gene |last6=Lewis |first6=Kari |last7=Kastner |first7=Jason |last8=Schimmels |first8=Kathy |last9=Kirby |first9=Karen |date=March 4, 2017 |title=2017 IEEE Aerospace Conference |conference=2017 IEEE Aerospace Conference |location=Big Sky, Montana |pages=1–12 |doi=10.1109/AERO.2017.7943832 |isbn=978-1-5090-1613-6 |chapter=Europa mission update: Beyond payload selection}} Specifically, the objectives are to study: * Ice shell and ocean: Confirm the existence, and characterize the nature, of water within or beneath the ice, and processes of surface-ice-ocean exchange * Composition: Distribution and chemistry of key compounds and the links to ocean composition * Geology: Characteristics and formation of surface features, including sites of recent or current activity. === Strategy === [[File:Europa_Clipper_Radiation.png|thumb|upright=1.1|left|A wide orbit of Jupiter with several flybys of Europa will minimize radiation exposure and increase data transfer speed.]] Because Europa lies well within the harsh radiation fields surrounding Jupiter, even a radiation-hardened spacecraft in near orbit would be functional for just a few months.{{Cite news |last=Kane |first=Van |date=August 26, 2014 |title=Europa: How Less Can Be More |publisher=Planetary Society |url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/guest-blogs/van-kane/20140826-europa-how-less-can-be-more.html |url-status=live |access-date=August 29, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191117080735/https://www.planetary.org/blogs/guest-blogs/van-kane/20140826-europa-how-less-can-be-more.html |archive-date=November 17, 2019}} Most instruments can gather data far faster than the communications system can transmit it to Earth because there are a limited number of antennas available on Earth to receive the scientific data. Therefore, another key limiting factor on science for a Europa orbiter is the time available to return data to Earth. In contrast, the amount of time during which the instruments can make close-up observations is less important. Studies by scientists from the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] show that by performing several flybys with many months to return data, the ''Europa Clipper'' concept will enable a US$2 billion mission to conduct the most crucial measurements of the cancelled US$4.3 billion [[Jupiter Europa Orbiter]] concept. Between each of the flybys, the spacecraft will have seven to ten days to transmit data stored during each brief encounter. That will let the spacecraft have up to a year of time to transmit its data compared to just 30 days for an orbiter. The result will be almost three times as much data returned to [[Earth]], while reducing exposure to radiation. The ''Europa Clipper'' will not orbit Europa, but instead orbit [[Jupiter]] and conduct 44 [[List of planetary flybys|flyby]]s of Europa at altitudes from 25 km to 2,700km (16 mi to 1,678 mi) each during its 3.5-year mission.{{Cite journal |last1=Phillips |first1=Cynthia B. |author-link=Cynthia B. Phillips |last2=Pappalardo |first2=Robert T. |date=May 20, 2014 |title=Europa Clipper Mission Concept |journal=Eos Transactions |publisher=Eos Transactions American Geophysical Union |volume=95 |issue=20 |pages=165–167 |bibcode=2014EOSTr..95..165P |doi=10.1002/2014EO200002 |doi-access=free}}{{Cite web |title=Europa Clipper |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/missions/europa-clipper/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210323162742/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/missions/europa-clipper |archive-date=March 23, 2021 |access-date=January 2, 2019 |publisher=NASA (JPL)}} {{PD-notice}} A key feature of the mission concept is that the ''Clipper'' would use [[gravity assist]]s from [[Europa (moon)|Europa]], [[Ganymede (moon)|Ganymede]] and [[Callisto (moon)|Callisto]] to change its trajectory, allowing the spacecraft to return to a different close approach point with each flyby.[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2014EO200002/pdf Europa Clipper Mission Concept: Exploring Jupiter's Ocean Moon] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819222413/http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2014EO200002/pdf |date=August 19, 2014 }}, [[Cynthia B. Phillips]], and Robert T. Pappalardo. ''Eos, Transactions American Geophysical Union'', Volume 95, Issue 20, May 20, 2014 Each flyby would cover a different sector of Europa in order to achieve a medium-quality global topographic survey, including ice thickness.{{Cite news |last=Kane |first=Van |date=May 26, 2013 |title=Europa Clipper Update |publisher=Future Planetary Exploration |url=http://futureplanets.blogspot.com/2013/05/europa-clipper-update.html |url-status=live |access-date=December 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210204070619/http://futureplanets.blogspot.com/2013/05/europa-clipper-update.html |archive-date=February 4, 2021}} The ''Europa Clipper'' could conceivably flyby at low altitude through the plumes of water vapor erupting from the moon's ice crust, thus sampling its subsurface ocean without having to land on the surface and drill through the ice. The spacecraft is expected to receive a total ionizing dose of 2.8 [[megarad]] during the mission. Shielding from Jupiter's harsh radiation belt will be provided by a radiation vault with {{convert|0.3|in|mm}} thick aluminum alloy walls, which will enclose the spacecraft electronics.{{Cite web |title=Meet Europa Clipper |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/meet-europa-clipper/ |access-date=November 11, 2022 |publisher=NASA}} To maximize the effectiveness of this shielding, the electronics will also be nested in the core of the spacecraft for additional radiation protection. == Design and construction == [[File:Europa-Clipper-Diagram.png|thumb|Spacecraft diagram]] [[File:Europa Clipper spacecraft best 140912jpg.jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|The spacecraft will make close flybys of Jupiter's moon, Europa.]] [[File:Magnetic Field of the Europa Clipper Spacecraft.gif|thumb|upright=1.0|right|Magnetic field of the Europa Clipper spacecraft]] === Power === Both [[radioisotope thermoelectric generator]] (RTG) and [[photovoltaics|photovoltaic]] power sources were assessed to power the orbiter.A. Eremenko ''et al.'', "Europa Clipper spacecraft configuration evolution", ''2014 IEEE Aerospace Conference'', pp. 1–13, Big Sky, MT, March 1–8, 2014 Although solar power is only 4% as intense at Jupiter as it is in Earth's orbit, powering a Jupiter orbital spacecraft by [[Solar panels on spacecraft|solar panels]] was demonstrated by the [[Juno (spacecraft)|''Juno'' mission]]. The alternative to solar panels was a [[multi-mission radioisotope thermoelectric generator]] (MMRTG), fueled with [[plutonium-238]]. The power source has already been demonstrated in the [[Mars Science Laboratory]] (MSL) mission. Five units were available, with one reserved for the [[Mars 2020 rover mission]] and another as backup. In September 2013, it was decided that the solar array was the less expensive option to power the spacecraft, and on October 3, 2014, it was announced that solar panels were chosen to power ''Europa Clipper''. The mission's designers determined that solar power was both cheaper than plutonium and practical to use on the spacecraft. Despite the increased weight of solar panels compared to plutonium-powered generators, the vehicle's mass had been projected to still be within acceptable launch limits.{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=October 8, 2014 |title=Europa Clipper Opts for Solar Power over Nuclear |url=http://spacenews.com/42121europa-clipper-opts-for-solar-power-over-nuclear/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://archive.today/20150209194443/http://spacenews.com/42121europa-clipper-opts-for-solar-power-over-nuclear/ |archive-date=February 9, 2015 |access-date=February 8, 2015 |publisher=SpaceNews}} Initial analysis suggest that each panel will have a surface area of {{cvt|18|sqm}} and produce 150 watts continuously when pointed towards the Sun while orbiting Jupiter.{{Cite news |last=Dreier |first=Casey |date=September 5, 2013 |title=NASA's Europa Mission Concept Rejects ASRGs – May Use Solar Panels at Jupiter Instead |publisher=The Planetary Society |url=http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2013/20130905-no-asrgs-for-europa.html |url-status=live |access-date=December 13, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180710011405/http://www.planetary.org/blogs/casey-dreier/2013/20130905-no-asrgs-for-europa.html |archive-date=July 10, 2018}} While in Europa's shadow, batteries will enable the spacecraft to continue gathering data. However, [[ionizing radiation]] can damage solar panels. The ''Europa Clipper''{{'s}} orbit will pass through Jupiter's intense magnetosphere, which is expected to gradually degrade the solar panels as the mission progresses. The solar panels will be provided by [[Airbus Defence and Space]], [[Netherlands]].{{Cite magazine |date=March 2018 |title=Spacecraft Highlights |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/system/internal_resources/details/original/116_Europa-Clipper-Newsletter-External-vol2issue1_FINAL.pdf |url-status=live |magazine=The Sextant – Europa Clipper Newsletter |publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory |volume=2 |issue=1 |page=3 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134354/https://europa.nasa.gov/system/internal_resources/details/original/116_Europa-Clipper-Newsletter-External-vol2issue1_FINAL.pdf |archive-date=October 10, 2022 |access-date=September 20, 2018}} {{PD-notice}} === Propulsion === The propulsion subsystem is built by [[Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory]] in [[Laurel, Maryland]]. It is {{cvt|10|ft}} tall, {{cvt|5|ft}} in diameter and comprises about two-thirds of the spacecraft's main body. The propulsion module carries nearly {{cvt|6000|lb}} of [[monomethyl hydrazine]] + [[dinitrogen tetroxide]] propellant , 50% to 60% of which will be used for the 6-8 hour Jupiter orbit insertion burn. The spacecraft has a total of 24 rocket engines (including eight backup) for attitude control and propulsion. === Scientific payload === The ''Europa Clipper'' mission is equipped with a sophisticated suite of 9 instruments to study Europa's interior and [[ocean]], [[geology]], [[chemistry]], and [[habitability]]. The electronic components will be protected from the intense radiation by a 150-kilogram [[titanium]] and aluminum shield. The spacecraft payload and trajectory are subject to change as the mission design matures.{{Cite conference |last1=Amato |first1=Michael J. |last2=Spidaliere |first2=P. |last3=Mahaffy |first3=P. |year=2016 |title=Biosignature Explorer for Europa (BEE) Probe – The Concept for Directly Searching for Life Evidence on Europa at Lower Cost and Risk |url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2602.pdf |conference=47th Lunar and Planetary Science Conference |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170122232905/http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/2602.pdf |archive-date=January 22, 2017 |access-date=September 28, 2016 |url-status=live}} The nine science instruments for the orbiter, announced in May 2015, have an estimated total mass of {{cvt|82|kg}} and are listed below:{{Cite news |date=May 26, 2015 |title=NASA's Europa Mission Begins with Selection of Science Instruments |publisher=NASA (JPL) |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4598 |url-status=live |access-date=May 27, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200926192203/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4598 |archive-date=September 26, 2020}} {{PD-notice}} ==== Europa Thermal Emission Imaging System (E-THEMIS) ==== The [[Europa Thermal Emission Imaging System]] will provide high spatial resolution as well as multi-spectral imaging of the surface of Europa in the [[Infrared|mid]] to [[far infrared]] bands to help detect geologically active sites and areas, such as potential vents erupting plumes of water into space. This instrument is derived from the [[Thermal Emission Imaging System]] (THEMIS) on the ''[[2001 Mars Odyssey]]'' orbiter, also developed by Philip Christensen.{{Cite web |date=April 25, 2019 |title=E-THEMIS {{!}} Christensen Research Group |url=http://christensen.asu.edu/instrument/e-themis/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134358/https://christensen.asu.edu/instrument/e-themis/ |archive-date=October 10, 2022 |access-date=May 14, 2021 |website=Christensen Research Group |publisher=[[Arizona State University]]}} * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Philip Christensen, [[Arizona State University]]}} ==== Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa (MISE) ==== The [[Mapping Imaging Spectrometer for Europa]] is an imaging [[Infrared spectroscopy|near infrared spectrometer]] to probe the surface composition of Europa, identifying and mapping the distributions of [[organic compound|organics]] (including [[amino acid]]s and [[tholin]]s[http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017AAS...22913804W MISE: A Search for Organics on Europa] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181116052227/http://adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2017AAS...22913804W |date=November 16, 2018 }}, Whalen, Kelly; Lunine, Jonathan I.; [[Diana Blaney|Blaney, Diana L.]]; ''American Astronomical Society'', AAS Meeting #229, id.138.04, January 2017{{Cite news |date=May 27, 2015 |title=Europa Mission to Probe Magnetic Field and Chemistry |publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4602 |url-status=live |access-date=October 23, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201202163713/https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4602 |archive-date=December 2, 2020}} {{PD-notice}}), salts, acid hydrates, water ice phases, and other materials. From these measurements, scientists expect to be able to relate the moon's surface composition to the habitability of its ocean.{{Cite news |last=Blaney |first=Diana L.|author-link=Diana Blaney |date=2010 |title=Europa Composition Using Visible to Short Wavelength Infrared Spectroscopy |work=JPL |publisher=American Astronomical Society, DPS meeting #42, #26.04; Bulletin of the American Astronomical Society, Vol. 42, page 1025}} MISE is built in collaboration with the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory (APL). * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' [[Diana Blaney]], [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]}} ==== Europa Imaging System (EIS) ==== The [[Europa Imaging System]] is a [[visible spectrum]] wide and narrow angle camera instrument that will map most of Europa at {{cvt|50|m}} resolution, and will provide images of selected surface areas at up to {{cvt|0.5|m|in}} resolution.{{Cite web |last1=Turtle |first1=Elizabeth |author-link=Elizabeth Turtle |last2=Mcewen |first2=Alfred |author-link2=Alfred McEwen |last3=Collins |first3=G. |last4=Fletcher |first4=L. |last5=Hansen |first5=C. |last6=Hayes |first6=A. |last7=Hurford |first7=T. |last8=Kirk |first8=R. |last9=Mlinar |first9=A.C. |title=THE EUROPA IMAGING SYSTEM (EIS): HIGH RESOLUTION IMAGING AND TOPOGRAPHY TO INVESTIGATE EUROPA'S GEOLOGY, ICE SHELL, AND POTENTIAL FOR CURRENT ACTIVITY. |url=https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/1626.pdf |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210305231100/https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/1626.pdf |archive-date=March 5, 2021 |access-date=May 14, 2021 |publisher=Universities Space Research Association}} * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Elizabeth Turtle, [[Applied Physics Laboratory]]}} ==== Europa Ultraviolet Spectrograph (Europa-UVS) ==== The [[Europa Ultraviolet Spectrograph]] instrument will be able to detect small plumes and will provide valuable data about the composition and dynamics of the moon's [[exosphere]]. The principal investigator Kurt Retherford was part of a group that discovered plumes erupting from Europa while using the [[Hubble Space Telescope]] in the [[Ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy|UV spectrum]].{{Cite journal |last=Roth |first=Lorenz |year=2014 |title=Transient Water Vapor at Europa's South Pole |journal=Science |volume=343 |issue=171 |pages=171–4 |bibcode=2014Sci...343..171R |doi=10.1126/science.1247051 |issn=1095-9203 |pmid=24336567 |s2cid=27428538}}|access-date=May 27, 2015 * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Kurt Retherford, [[Southwest Research Institute]]}} ==== Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface (REASON) ==== The [[Radar for Europa Assessment and Sounding: Ocean to Near-surface]] (REASON){{Cite news |date=June 1, 2015 |title=Radar Techniques Used in Antarctica Will Scour Europa for Life-Supporting Environments |publisher=University of Texas Austin |url=http://astrobiology.com/2015/06/radar-techniques-used-in-antarctica-will-scour-europa-for-life-supporting-environments.html |url-status=live |access-date=June 4, 2015 |archive-url=https://archive.today/20151115171717/http://astrobiology.com/2015/06/radar-techniques-used-in-antarctica-will-scour-europa-for-life-supporting-environments.html |archive-date=November 15, 2015}}{{Cite journal |last1=Grima |first1=Cyril |last2=Schroeder |first2=Dustin |last3=Blakenship |first3=Donald D. |last4=Young |first4=Duncan A. |date=November 15, 2014 |title=Planetary landing-zone reconnaissance using ice-penetrating radar data: Concept validation in Antarctica |journal=Planetary and Space Science |volume=103 |pages=191–204 |bibcode=2014P&SS..103..191G |doi=10.1016/j.pss.2014.07.018 |doi-access=free}} is a dual-frequency [[Radioglaciology|ice penetrating radar]] instrument that is designed to characterize and sound Europa's ice crust from the near-surface to the ocean, revealing the hidden structure of Europa's ice shell and potential water pockets within. This instrument will be built by [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]]. * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Donald Blankenship, [[University of Texas at Austin]]}} ==== Interior Characterization of Europa using Magnetometry (ICEMAG) ==== The [[Interior Characterization of Europa using Magnetometry]] (ICEMAG) was '''cancelled''' due to cost overruns.{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=March 6, 2019 |title=NASA to replace Europa Clipper instrument |url=https://spacenews.com/nasa-to-replace-europa-clipper-instrument/ |access-date=April 26, 2019 |publisher=SpaceNews}} ICEMAG will be replaced by a simpler magnetometer.{{Cite web |date=March 5, 2019 |title=NASA Seeks New Options for Science Instrument on Europa Clipper |url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/nasa-seeks-new-options-for-science-instrument-on-europa-clipper/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210219064432/https://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/nasa-seeks-new-options-for-science-instrument-on-europa-clipper/ |archive-date=February 19, 2021 |access-date=March 13, 2019 |publisher=NASA}} {{PD-notice}} ==== Europa Clipper Magnetometer (ECM) ==== Replacing the ICEMAG instrument, [[Europa Clipper Magnetometer]] (ECM) will be used to characterize the magnetic fields around Europa. The instrument consists of three magnetic flux gates placed along a 25ft boom, which will be stowed during launch and deployed afterwards.{{Cite web |title=ECM Instruments- NASA's Europa Clipper |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/ecm/ |access-date=October 11, 2022 |publisher=NASA}} By studying the strength and orientation of Europa's magnetic field over multiple flybys, scientists hope to be able to confirm the existence of Europa's subsurface ocean, as well as characterize the thickness of its icy crust and measure the water's depth and salinity.{{Cite web |title=ECM: How We'll Use It |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/ecm/#otp_how_we'll_use_it |access-date=October 11, 2022 |publisher=NASA}} * {{small|'''Instrument Team Lead:''' Margaret Kivelson, [[University of Michigan]]}} ==== Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS) ==== [[File:Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS).tif|thumb|Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS). Pictured in a clean room at APL are the recently assembled Faraday cup sensors and instrument housings in two configurations. On the left is the final flight hardware, with insulating thermal blankets installed; on the right is a test configuration that protects sensitive hardware for transportation.]] The [[Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding]] (PIMS) measures the [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] surrounding Europa to characterise the magnetic fields generated by plasma currents. These plasma currents mask the [[Electromagnetic induction|magnetic induction]] response of Europa's subsurface ocean. In conjunction with a magnetometer, it is key to determining Europa's ice shell thickness, ocean depth, and salinity. PIMS will also probe the mechanisms responsible for weathering and releasing material from Europa's surface into the [[atmosphere]] and [[ionosphere]] and understanding how Europa influences its local space environment and Jupiter's [[magnetosphere]].{{Cite conference |last1=Westlake |first1=Joseph |last2=Rymer |first2=A. M. |last3=Kasper |first3=J. C. |last4=McNutt |first4=R. L. |last5=Smith |first5=H. T. |last6=Stevens |first6=M. L. |last7=Parker |first7=C. |last8=Case |first8=A. W. |last9=Ho |first9=G. C. |date=2014 |title=The Influence of Magnetospheric Plasma on Magnetic Sounding of Europa's Interior Oceans |url=https://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/icyworlds2014/pdf/4032.pdf |conference=Workshop on the Habitability of Icy Worlds (2014) |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610204847/http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/icyworlds2014/pdf/4032.pdf |archive-date=June 10, 2016 |access-date=May 27, 2015 |last10=Mitchell |first10=D. G. |url-status=live}}{{Cite journal |last=Joseph |first=Westlake |date=December 14, 2015 |title=The Plasma Instrument for Magnetic Sounding (PIMS): Enabling Required Plasma Measurements for the Exploration of Europa |url=https://agu.confex.com/agu/fm15/webprogram/Paper66117.html |url-status=live |journal=AGU Fall Meeting Abstracts |publisher=AGU |volume=2015 |pages=P13E–09 |bibcode=2015AGUFM.P13E..09W |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170123035543/https://agu.confex.com/agu/fm15/webprogram/Paper66117.html |archive-date=January 23, 2017 |access-date=June 21, 2016}} * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Joseph Westlake, [[Applied Physics Laboratory]]}} ==== Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration (MASPEX) ==== The [[Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration]] (MASPEX) will determine the composition of the surface and subsurface ocean by measuring Europa's extremely tenuous atmosphere and any surface materials ejected into space. Jack Waite, who led development of MASPEX, was also Science Team Lead of the [[Cassini–Huygens|Ion and Neutral Mass Spectrometer]] (INMS) on the ''[[Cassini–Huygens|Cassini]]'' spacecraft.{{Cite web |title=Mass Spectrometer for Planetary Exploration / Europa (MASPEX) |url=https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experiment/display.action?id=EUROPA-CL-08 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210519011818/https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experiment/display.action?id=EUROPA-CL-08 |archive-date=May 19, 2021 |access-date=May 18, 2021 |website=[[NASA Space Science Data Coordinated Archive]] |publisher=[[NASA]]}}{{Cite web |last1=Waite |first1=Jack |last2=Lewis |first2=W. |last3=Kasprzak |first3=W. |last4=Anicich |first4=V. |last5=Block |first5=B. |last6=Cravens |first6=T. |last7=Fletcher |first7=G. |last8=Ip |first8=W. |last9=Luhmann |first9=J |date=August 13, 1998 |title=THE CASSINI ION AND NEUTRAL MASS SPECTROMETER (INMS) INVESTIGATION |url=https://www.lpl.arizona.edu/~yelle/eprints/Waite04a.pdf |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211228164227/https://www.lpl.arizona.edu/~yelle/eprints/Waite04a.pdf |archive-date=December 28, 2021 |access-date=May 18, 2021 |website=[[Lunar and Planetary Laboratory]] |publisher=[[University of Arizona]]}} * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Jim Burch, [[Southwest Research Institute]]}} ==== Surface Dust Analyzer (SUDA) ==== [[File:Europa Clipper's Dust Analyzer sensor head.jpg|thumb|Europa Clipper's Dust Analyzer sensor head]] The [[Surface Dust Analyser|SUrface Dust Analyzer]] (SUDA) is a [[Mass spectrometry|mass spectrometer]] that will measure the composition of small solid particles ejected from Europa, providing the opportunity to directly sample the surface and potential plumes on low-altitude flybys. The instrument is capable of identifying traces of organic and inorganic compounds in the ice of ejecta.{{Cite journal |last=Kempf |first=Sascha |display-authors=etal |date=May 2012 |title=Linear high resolution dust mass spectrometer for a mission to the Galilean satellites |journal=Planetary and Space Science |volume=65 |issue=1 |pages=10–20 |bibcode=2012P&SS...65...10K |doi=10.1016/j.pss.2011.12.019}} Scientists expect SUDA to be able to detect a single cell in an ice grain.{{cite journal |doi=10.1126/sciadv.adl0849 |title=How to identify cell material in a single ice grain emitted from Enceladus or Europa |date=2024 |last1=Klenner |first1=Fabian |last2=Bönigk |first2=Janine |last3=Napoleoni |first3=Maryse |last4=Hillier |first4=Jon |last5=Khawaja |first5=Nozair |last6=Olsson-Francis |first6=Karen |last7=Cable |first7=Morgan L. |last8=Malaska |first8=Michael J. |last9=Kempf |first9=Sascha |last10=Abel |first10=Bernd |last11=Postberg |first11=Frank |journal=Science Advances |volume=10 |issue=12 |pages=eadl0849 |pmid=38517965 |pmc=10959401 }} * {{small|'''Principal investigator:''' Sascha Kempf, [[University of Colorado Boulder]]}} ==== Gravity/Radio Science ==== [[File:PIA22773 Europa Clipper Antenna Prototype.jpg|thumb|A full-scale prototype of the high-gain antenna on Europa Clipper spacecraft is undergoing testing in the Experimental Test Range at NASA's Langley Research Center in Hampton, Virginia]] While not intended for use specifically as an instrument, Clipper will be using its radio antenna to perform additional experiments and learn about Europa's gravitational field. As the spacecraft performs each of its 45 flybys, its trajectory will be subtly altered by the moon's gravity. By sending radio signals between Earth and the moon and characterizing the [[Doppler shift]] in the return signal, scientists at JPL will be able to create a detailed characterization of the spacecraft's motion. This data will help to determine how Europa flexes in relation to its distance from Jupiter, which will in turn reveal information about the moon's internal structure and tidal motions. {{Cite web |title=Gravity/Radio Science Instruments |url=https://europa.nasa.gov/spacecraft/instruments/gravity-radio-science/ |access-date=November 12, 2022 |publisher=NASA}} * {{small|'''Team lead:''' Erwan Mazarico [[Goddard Space Flight Center]]}} === Proposed secondary elements === The ''Europa Clipper'' mission considered an extra mass of about {{convert|250|kg|lbs}} to carry an additional flight element. About a dozen proposals have been suggested but none went beyond the concept study phase and none are planned for the Europa Clipper mission. A few of these are described below. ==== Nanosatellites ==== Since the ''Europa Clipper'' mission may not be able to easily modify its orbital trajectory or altitude to fly through the episodic water [[Europa (moon)#Plumes|plumes]], scientists and engineers working on the mission have investigated deploying from the spacecraft several [[miniaturized satellite]]s of the [[CubeSat]] format, possibly driven by [[ion thruster]]s, to fly through the plumes and assess the habitability of Europa's internal ocean.{{Cite news |date=October 8, 2014 |title=JPL Selects Europa CubeSat Proposals for Study |work=Jet Propulsion Laboratory |publisher=NASA |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4330 |url-status=live |access-date=April 17, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201111202713/http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=4330 |archive-date=November 11, 2020}} {{PD-notice}} Some early proposals include ''Mini-MAGGIE'',{{Cite web |last1=Burgett |first1=B. |last2=Long |first2=J. |last3=Whaley |first3=P. |last4=Raz |first4=A. |last5=Herrick |first5=R.R. |last6=Thorsen |first6=D. |last7=Delamere |first7=P. |date=2016 |title=Mini-MAGGIE: CubeSat MAGnetism and Gravity Investigation at Europa |url=http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/1928.pdf |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170122232842/http://www.hou.usra.edu/meetings/lpsc2016/pdf/1928.pdf |archive-date=January 22, 2017 |access-date=October 10, 2022 |publisher=Lunar and Planetary Science Conference}} ''DARCSIDE'' (Deployable Atmospheric Reconnaissance CubeSat with Sputtering Ion Detector at Europa),{{Cite web |last1=Chanover |first1=Nancy |last2=Murphy |first2=James |last3=Rankin |first3=Kyle |last4=Stochaj |first4=Steven |last5=Thelen |first5=Alexander |date=August 31, 2016 |title=CubeSat Session I: Beyond LEO |url=http://digitalcommons.usu.edu/smallsat/2016/S1BeyondLEO/4/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201124073401/http://digitalcommons.usu.edu/smallsat/2016/S1BeyondLEO/4/ |archive-date=November 24, 2020 |access-date=October 10, 2022 |publisher=Small Satellites Conference}}[http://www.jossonline.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Final-Thelen-A-Europa-CubeSat-Concept-Study-for-Measuring-Atmospheric-Density-and-Heavy-Ion-Flux.pdf A Europa CubeSat Concept Study for Measuring Atmospheric Density and Heavy Ion Flux] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180413094402/http://www.jossonline.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Final-Thelen-A-Europa-CubeSat-Concept-Study-for-Measuring-Atmospheric-Density-and-Heavy-Ion-Flux.pdf |date=April 13, 2018 }}, Thelen, A. et al., (2017): ''Journal of Small Satellites'', Vol. 6, No. 2, pp. 591–607 ''Sylph''[http://digitalcommons.usu.edu/smallsat/2016/TS11SciPayload1/6/ Sylph – A SmallSat Probe Concept Engineered to Answer Europa's Big Question] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210122034601/http://digitalcommons.usu.edu/smallsat/2016/TS11SciPayload1/6/ |date=January 22, 2021 }}, 2016 and CSALT. These concepts were funded for preliminary studies but none were considered for hardware development or flight. The ''Europa Clipper'' would have relayed signals from the nanosatellites back to [[Earth]]. With propulsion, some nanosatellites could also be capable of entering orbit around Europa. ==== Secondary orbiters ==== ===== Biosignature Explorer for Europa ===== NASA was also assessing the release of an additional {{cvt|250|kg}} probe called ''Biosignature Explorer for Europa'' (BEE), that would have been equipped with a basic bi-propellant engine and cold gas thrusters to be more agile and responsive to the episodic activity on Europa and sample and analyze the water plumes for [[biosignature]]s and life evidence before they are destroyed by radiation. The BEE plume probe would have been equipped with a proven [[Mass spectrometry|mass spectrometer]] combined with [[Gas chromatography|gas chromatograph]] separation. It would also carry an [[ultraviolet]] (UV) plume targeting camera as well as [[Visible spectrum|visible]] and [[infrared camera]]s to image the active region with better resolution than the ''Clipper'' mother ship instruments. The BEE probe would have flown through at {{cvt|2|to|10|km|mi}} altitude, then made a quick exit and performed its analysis far from the radiation belts. ===== Europa Tomography Probe ===== [[File:1-pia25957 europa-clipper-hga-installation-in-progress-1041.jpg|thumb|Engineers and technicians install Europa Clipper's high-gain antenna in the main clean room at JPL.]] A European proposal, the Europa Tomography Probe, was a concept for an independent powered spacecraft equipped with a [[magnetometer]] that would orbit Europa on a polar orbit for at least six months. It would have determined the deep interior structure of Europa and provided a good determination of the ice shell thickness and ocean depth, which arguably cannot be done accurately by multiple flybys. ==== Impactor probes ==== Some proposed impactor probe concepts include those by the [[Netherlands]],[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11038-017-9508-7, An Impacting Descent Probe for Europa and the Other Galilean Moons of Jupiter] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221010134357/https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11038-017-9508-7, |date=October 10, 2022 }}, Wurz, P., Lasi, D., Thomas, N. et al., ''Earth Moon Planets'' (2017) 120: 113, {{doi|10.1007/s11038-017-9508-7}} and [[United Kingdom]].[https://research-information.bristol.ac.uk/files/70486876/Europa.pdf Europa's small impactor flux and seismic detection predictions] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180723053355/https://research-information.bristol.ac.uk/files/70486876/Europa.pdf |date=July 23, 2018 }}, Tsu ji, D., and Teanby, N. A., (2016), ''Icarus'', 277, 39–55. {{doi |10.1016/j.icarus.2016.04.036}} ==== Flyby sample return ==== The ''Europa Life Signature Assayer'' (ELSA) concept by the [[University of Colorado]] consisted of a probe that could have been flown as a secondary payload. ELSA would have used a small impactor to create a plume of subsurface particles and catapulted them to altitudes where it would have been able to pass through to collect samples and analyze them on board.[https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20170002063.pdf TRAJECTORY AND NAVIGATION DESIGN FOR AN IMPACTOR MISSION CONCEPT] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200731042441/https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/20170002063.pdf |date=July 31, 2020 }}, Andres Dono Perez, Roland Burtony, Jan Stuplz, and David Mauro, 2017, NASA AAS 17-487 {{PD-notice}}[https://www.colorado.edu/aerospace/sites/default/files/attached-files/elsa_aiaa.pdf Project ELSA: Europa Lander for Science Acquisition] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180105123057/https://www.colorado.edu/aerospace/sites/default/files/attached-files/elsa_aiaa.pdf |date=January 5, 2018 }}, Darren Combs, Gabe Frank, Sara Grandone, Colton Hall, Daniel Johnson, Trevor Luke, Scott Mende, Daniel Nowicki, Ben Stringer, University of Colorado, Boulder, 2017 A variation of this concept is the 1996 ''Ice Clipper'', which involves a {{convert|10|kg|lb|adj=on}} impactor that would be jettisoned from the main spacecraft to impact Europa, thereby creating a debris cloud in nearby space about {{convert|100|km|mi|sp=us}} altitude, subsequently sampled by a small spacecraft on a close flyby and use Europa's gravitational force for a [[Free-return trajectory|free return trajectory]].[http://drewryanjones.com/assets/conf_paper_2016_no3.pdf Trajectories for Europa Flyby Sample Return] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200731023937/http://drewryanjones.com/assets/conf_paper_2016_no3.pdf |date=July 31, 2020 }}, Drew Ryan Jones, JPL"Planetary Protection for a Europa Surface Sample Return: The Ice Clipper Mission", Chris McKay, ''Advances in Space Research'', Vol. 30, No. 6, 2002, pp. 1601–1605"Europa Ice Clipper: A Discovery class sample return mission to Europa", Chris McKay et al., Proposal from NASA Ames Research Center to NASA HQ submitted December 11, 1996 {{PD-notice}} The collection mechanism is tentatively considered to be [[aerogel]] (similar to [[Stardust (spacecraft)|''Stardust'' mission]]). === Add-on lander history === An early ''Europa Clipper'' concept called for including a stationary lander about {{convert|1|m|ft|sigfig=1}} in diameter, perhaps about {{cvt|230|kg}} with a maximum of {{cvt|30|kg}} for instruments plus propellant. Suggested instruments were a [[mass spectrometer]] and a [[Raman spectrometer]] to determine the chemistry of the surface. The lander was proposed to be delivered to Europa by the main spacecraft and possibly require the [[Mars Science Laboratory#Sky crane|sky crane system]] for a high precision, soft landing near an active crevasse.{{Cite news |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=November 17, 2015 |title=Attempt no landing there? Yeah right—we're going to Europa |pages=1–3 |publisher=Ars Technica |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2015/11/attempt-no-landing-there-yeah-right-were-going-to-europa/ |url-status=live |access-date=January 5, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110122700/http://arstechnica.com/science/2015/11/attempt-no-landing-there-yeah-right-were-going-to-europa/ |archive-date=January 10, 2016}} The lander would have operated about 10 days on the surface using battery power. The ''Europa Clipper'' would take about three years to image 95% of the surface of Europa at about {{convert|50|m|ft}} per pixel. With this data, scientists could then find a suitable landing site. By one estimate, including a lander could add as much as US$1 billion to the mission's cost. ====Separate launch==== {{main|Europa Lander}} [[File:PIA21048 - Europa Lander Mission Concept (Artist's Rendering).jpg|thumb|upright=1.0|right|An artist's impression of the separately launched [[Europa Lander]] mission (2017 design)]] It was determined in February 2017 that designing a system capable of landing on a surface about which very little is known bears too much risk, and that the ''Europa Clipper'' will lay the foundation for a future landing mission by performing detailed reconnaissance first.{{Cite web |date=February 8, 2017 |title=NASA Receives Science Report on Europa Lander Concept |url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-receives-science-report-on-europa-lander-concept |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201112015154/https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-receives-science-report-on-europa-lander-concept |archive-date=November 12, 2020 |access-date=October 10, 2022 |publisher=NASA}}{{PD-notice}} This led to a stand-alone mission proposal in 2017: the [[Europa Lander (NASA)|Europa Lander]].{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=July 18, 2017 |title=JPL moves ahead with Mars and Europa missions despite funding uncertainty |url=http://spacenews.com/jpl-moves-ahead-with-mars-and-europa-missions-despite-funding-uncertainty/ |website=SpaceNews}} The NASA Europa Lander, if funded, would be launched separately in 2025{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=February 17, 2019 |title=Final fiscal year 2019 budget bill secures US$21.5 billion for NASA |url=https://spacenews.com/final-fiscal-year-2019-budget-bill-secures-21-5-billion-for-nasa/ |website=SpaceNews}} to complement the studies by the ''Europa Clipper'' mission.{{Cite web |title=NASA Receives Science Report on Europa Lander Concept |url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=6737 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170216052238/http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=6737 |archive-date=February 16, 2017 |access-date=February 15, 2017 |publisher=NASA/JPL}} {{PD-notice}}[http://spacenews.com/nasa-weighing-dual-launches-of-europa-orbiter-and-lander/ NASA weighing dual launches of Europa orbiter and lander], Joe Faust, SpaceNews, February 2016 If funded, approximately 10 proposals may be selected to proceed into a competitive process with a US$1.5 million budget per investigation.[https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-asks-scientific-community-to-think-on-possible-europa-lander-instruments NASA Asks Scientific Community to Think on Possible Europa Lander Instruments] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210219071024/https://www.nasa.gov/feature/nasa-asks-scientific-community-to-think-on-possible-europa-lander-instruments/ |date=February 19, 2021 }}, NASA News, May 17, 2017 {{PD-notice}} The President's 2018 and 2019 federal budget proposals did not fund the Europa Lander, but did assign US$195 million[https://www.aip.org/fyi/2018/fy19-appropriations-bills-nasa FY19 Appropriations Bills: NASA] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200213190947/https://www.aip.org/fyi/2018/fy19-appropriations-bills-nasa |date=February 13, 2020 }} – Europa Missions, American Institute of Physics, June 20, 2018 for concept studies.[https://spaceflightnow.com/2018/03/23/space-launch-system-planetary-exploration-get-big-boosts-in-nasa-budget/ Space Launch System, planetary exploration get big boosts in NASA budget] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190715134352/https://spaceflightnow.com/2018/03/23/space-launch-system-planetary-exploration-get-big-boosts-in-nasa-budget/ |date=July 15, 2019 }}, Stephen Clark, Spaceflight Now, March 23, 2018{{cite news|url=https://spacenews.com/europa-lander-concept-redesigned-to-lower-cost-and-complexity/|title= Europa lander concept redesigned to lower cost and complexity|author=Jeff Foust|date=March 29, 2018|publisher=[[Space News]]|access-date=July 4, 2023}} The 2022 omnibus spending bill allocates $14.2 million to Icy Satellites Surface Technology for a future Ocean Worlds lander mission (NASA had requested $5 million for the Europa Lander).{{Cite news |last=Smith |first=Marcia |date=March 10, 2022 |title=NASA TO GET $24 BILLION FOR FY2022, MORE THAN LAST YEAR BUT LESS THAN BIDEN WANTED |publisher=spacepolicyonline.com |url=https://spacepolicyonline.com/news/nasa-to-get-24-billion-for-fy2022-more-than-last-year-but-less-than-biden-wanted/ |url-status=live |access-date=March 15, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220313063009/https://spacepolicyonline.com/news/nasa-to-get-24-billion-for-fy2022-more-than-last-year-but-less-than-biden-wanted/ |archive-date=March 13, 2022}} == Launch and trajectory == The ~{{cvt|840|m/s|mph}} [[delta V]] Jupiter orbit insertion burn will take place at a distance of 11 Rj (Jovian radii) from the planet following a {{cvt|500|km|mi}} Ganymede gravity assist flyby to reduce spacecraft velocity by ~{{cvt|400|m/s|mph}}. After this, the spacecraft will perform a ~{{cvt|122|m/s|mph}} [[periapsis]] raise maneuver (PRM) rocket burn near the [[apoapsis]] of its initial 202-day period capture orbit.{{citation |last1=Buffington |first1=Brent |title=Trajectory Design for the Europa Clipper Mission Concept |date=5 August 2014 |url=https://www.trylam.com/CPP/AIAA_SPACE2014_Buffington_PrePrint_v2.pdf |access-date=11 May 2024 |language=en}} Congress had originally mandated that ''Europa Clipper'' be launched on NASA's [[Space Launch System]] (SLS) [[super heavy-lift launch vehicle]], but [[NASA]] had requested that other vehicles be allowed to launch the spacecraft due to a foreseen lack of available SLS vehicles.{{Cite web |last=Foust |first=Jeff |date=July 10, 2020 |title=Cost growth prompts changes to Europa Clipper instruments |url=https://spacenews.com/cost-growth-prompts-changes-to-europa-clipper-instruments/ |access-date=July 10, 2020 |publisher=SpaceNews}} The United States Congress's 2021 omnibus spending bill directed the NASA Administrator to conduct a full and open competition to select a commercial launch vehicle if the conditions to launch the probe on a SLS rocket cannot be met.{{Cite news |last=Howell |first=Elizabeth |date=December 22, 2020 |title=NASA receives US$23.3 billion for 2021 fiscal year in Congress' omnibus spending bill |publisher=SPACE.com |url=https://www.space.com/nasa-2021-budget-congress-omnibus-spending-bill |url-status=live |access-date=December 29, 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210116062645/https://www.space.com/nasa-2021-budget-congress-omnibus-spending-bill |archive-date=January 16, 2021}} On January 25, 2021, NASA's Planetary Missions Program Office formally directed the mission team to "immediately cease efforts to maintain SLS compatibility" and move forward with a commercial launch vehicle. On February 10, 2021, it was announced that the mission would use a 5.5-year trajectory to the Jovian system, with gravity-assist maneuvers involving Mars (February 2025) and Earth (December 2026). Launch is targeted for a 21-day period between October 10 and 30, 2024, giving an arrival date in April 2030, and backup launch dates were identified in 2025 and 2026. The SLS option would have entailed a direct trajectory to Jupiter taking less than three years. One alternative to the direct trajectory was identified as using a commercial rocket, with a longer 6-year cruise time involving [[gravity assist]] maneuvers at [[Venus]], [[Earth]] and/or [[Mars]]. Additionally, a launch on a [[Delta IV Heavy]] with a gravity assist at Venus was considered.{{Cite web |last=Berger |first=Eric |author-link=Eric Berger (meteorologist) |date=July 23, 2021 |title=SpaceX to launch the Europa Clipper mission for a bargain price |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805032226/https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/ |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |access-date=October 10, 2022 |publisher=[[Ars Technica]]}} In July 2021 Falcon Heavy was chosen to launch the spacecraft. Three reasons were given: launch cost, SLS availability, and "shaking". The move to Falcon Heavy saved an estimated US$2 billion in launch costs alone.{{Cite web |last=Ralph |first=Eric |title=SpaceX Falcon Heavy to launch NASA ocean moon explorer, saving the US billions |url=https://www.teslarati.com/spacex-falcon-heavy-nasa-ocean-moon-mission/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211128000524/https://www.teslarati.com/spacex-falcon-heavy-nasa-ocean-moon-mission/ |archive-date=November 28, 2021 |access-date=November 28, 2021 |website=Teslarati|date=July 25, 2021 }}{{Cite web |last=Berger |first=Eric |date=July 23, 2021 |title=SpaceX to launch the Europa Clipper mission for a bargain price |url=https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805032226/https://arstechnica.com/science/2021/07/spacex-to-launch-the-europa-clipper-mission-for-a-bargain-price/ |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |access-date=November 28, 2021 |website=arstechnica}} NASA was not sure an SLS would be available for the mission since the [[Artemis program]] would use SLS rockets extensively, and the SLS's use of [[solid rocket booster]]s (SRBs) generates more vibrations in the payload than a launcher that does not use SRBs. The cost to redesign Europa Clipper for the SLS vibratory environment was estimated at US$1 billion. {{multiple image | align = center | direction = horizontal | width = 300px | header = Animation of Europa Clipper | image1 = Animation of Europa Clipper trajectory.gif | caption1 = Around the Sun

{{legend2|Magenta|Europa Clipper}}{{·}}{{legend2|Cyan|Europa}}{{·}}{{legend2|Gold|Callisto}}{{·}}{{legend2|OrangeRed|Io}} | footer = }} ==Public outreach== [[File:Europa Clipper commemorative plate 1.jpg|thumb|Europa Clipper commemorative plate features waveforms that are visual representations of the sound waves formed by the word “water” in 103 languages]] [[File:Europa Clipper commemorative plate.jpg|thumb|This side of a commemorative plate mounted on NASA’s Europa Clipper spacecraft features U.S. Poet Laureate Ada Limón’s handwritten “In Praise of Mystery: A Poem for Europa.”]] To raise public awareness of the Europa Clipper mission, NASA undertook a "Message In A Bottle" campaign, i.e. actually "Send Your Name to Europa" campaign on 1 June 2023, through which people around the world are invited to send their names as signatories to a poem called, "In Praise of Mystery: A Poem for Europa" written by the U.S. Poet Laureate [[Ada Limón]]. The poem connects the two water worlds — Earth, yearning to reach out and understand what makes a world habitable, and Europa, waiting with secrets yet to be explored. The poem is engraved on ''Europa Clipper'' inside a [[tantalum]] metal plate that seals an opening into the vault. The inward-facing side of the metal plate is engraved with the poem in the poet's own handwriting, along with participants' names that will be etched onto a microchip attached to the plate, within an artwork of a wine bottle surrounded by the four [[Galilean moons]]. Together, the poem and names will travel 1.8 billion miles on Europa Clipper’s voyage to the Jupiter system. After registering their names, participants received a digital ticket with details of the mission's launch and destination. According to [[NASA]], 2,620,852 people signed their names to Europa Clipper's Message in a Bottle, most of whom were from the [[United States]].{{Cite web |title=NASA's Message in a Bottle |url=https://go.nasa.gov/455Yt0L |access-date=2024-03-24 |website=NASA's Europa Clipper |language=en}} The plate is about 7 by 11 inches (18 by 28 centimeters). The outward-facing panel features art that highlights Earth's connection to Europa. Linguists collected recordings of the word "water" spoken in 103 languages, from families of languages around the world. The audio files were converted into waveforms and etched into the plate. The waveforms radiate out from a symbol representing the [[American Sign Language]] sign for "water". Other elements etched on the inwards side together with the poem are the [[Drake Equation]], representations of the [[spectral line]]s of [[Hydrogen atom|atomic hydrogen]] and the [[hydroxyl radical]], together known as the [[Water hole (radio)|water hole]], and a portrait of planetary scientist [[Ron Greeley]].{{cite web |title=NASA Unveils Design for Message Heading to Jupiter's Moon Europa |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/nasa-unveils-design-for-message-heading-to-jupiters-moon-europa |website=NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) |access-date=11 March 2024}} {{PD-notice}}{{Cite web|url=https://astrobiology.com/2024/03/an-astrobiology-droid-asks-and-answers-how-many-ways-can-you-say-water.html|title=An Astrobiology Droid Asks And Answers 'How Many Ways Can You Say Water'?|first=Keith|last=Cowing|date=March 9, 2024|website=Astrobiology}} The research organization METI International gathered the audio files for the words for "water," and its president [[Douglas Vakoch]] designed the water hole component of the message.{{Cite web |last=Vakoch |first=Douglas |author-link=Douglas Vakoch |date=27 March 2024 |title=See the messages NASA is sending to Jupiter's icy moon, Europa |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg26134840-200-see-the-messages-nasa-is-sending-to-jupiters-icy-moon-europa/ |website=[[New Scientist]]}}{{Cite web |last=Vakoch |first=Douglas |author-link=Douglas Vakoch |date=March 28, 2024 |title=NASA’s mission to an ice-covered moon will contain a message between water worlds
